awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Engineering Pathways and Their Impact on Community and Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
The first year of an engineering program is a critical time period for undergraduate students who are evaluating whether or not they should continue in engineering. As a result, numerous first-year programs, courses, and experiences exist, with new ones created each year. While first-year engineering education is heavily dependent on the history, design, and political structure of the host institution, it remains important to use research results to inform the creation and alteration of the first-year engineering courses, programs, and experiences. Recent research investigations have generated knowledge of the differences in course structure and content if first-year engineering courses. However, faculty and administrators designing first-year engineering education commonly ask questions that are not addressed by current literature, such as "Is it better for students to have a common first-year experience or one that is discipline specific?" or "Should transfer students have a different course than freshmen?"  While it is likely that neither is better or worse, there are differences that must be investigated so faculty and administrators can make informed decisions regarding changes to first-year engineering education to enhance the student experience for all. This study intends to clarify how first-year engineering structure (e.g., common engineering, discipline specific), content (e.g., design, problem solving, academic success), and timing (e.g., one or two semesters) help or hinder students pursuing a variety of engineering pathways.

Through a three-phase exploratory qualitative case study employing individual interviews and focus groups, this study attempts to answer the research question: how do students who are pursuing engineering degrees through pathways that vary with respect to first-year engineering structure, content, and timing describe their experience participating in engineering communities of practice and their emerging engineering identities? Through the community of practice framework, this research determines what communities of practice are formed during first-year engineering and their relation to engineering identity in diverse first-year engineering experiences. The researchers are evaluating the differences in student development through the various experiences, focusing on the impacts of structure, content, and timing. Finally, the study investigates the alignment between institutional goals and the student experience. This project has four goals: 1) To understand the first-year engineering experience and the effects of that experience on students' engineering identity development; 2) To develop recommendations for promoting engineering communities of practice in first-year programs and courses; 3) To further the field's understanding of early engineer formation through triangulated data points; and 4) To develop design strategies for meeting institution-specific first-year engineering development goals. These goals have substantial positive impact on engineering education because they ensure that changes made in first-year engineering are beneficial and help ensure the success of first-year engineering students. Related to intellectual merit, this research parses out how first-year engineering structure, content, and timing help or hinder students' communities of practice and engineering identities to provide concrete evidence for methods that effectively support or oppose students' development and retention in the major.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Our work generated an understanding of how engineering students experience community and the transition from first-year engineering (FYE) student (i.e., freshman or entering transfer student) to the point where they enter (or choose not to enter) the engineering workforce. We interviewed 36 unique students over three years (some completing one, some completing two and some completing three interviews) at two different main institutions and two regional campuses connected to the main institutions to understand how the vastly different first-year engineering programs that they experienced contributed to their development as students and future engineers. Our interview questions had a purposeful emphasis on producing an understanding of how students developed their engineering identity (the belief that they are an engineer) and how students established supportive networks and communities within engineering. The project protocols (e.g., surveys and interview questions) and methods (e.g., procedures for writing extended memos) have been published and can be used in other research projects. 

 

The key findings (intellectual merit contributions) of this project are as follows: 

  • Across the pathways, students must claim their engineering identity. Often this is claimed after a significant engineering experience such an internship.  

  • Participants in the common first year structure were more likely to identify themselves as engineers because of their mindset or way of thinking than those in a direct matriculation structure.  

  • When engineering is not aligned with personal identity, students find an alternate career in which to use their engineering skills or focus on a new discipline or niche area within their current discipline.  

  • Though there are deliberate attempts to create community within FYE, these communities are not long-standing. Later in the degree program, communities form more naturally and in more diverse ways (e.g., study groups, professional organizations, special interests). These naturally formed communities tend to be more impactful than the communities formed within FYE.  

 

The broad impacts of this project are primarily in the area of improving teaching and learning in engineering. Key impacts are as follows: 

  • This project provided significant professional development for faculty in the area of engineering education. Project personnel led a workshop at a regional conference and seminars at their own institutions to develop skills in engineering education research methods. Project personnel also presented research results at teaching-focused conferences to develop expertise in designing FYE programs with consideration for engineering identity development and community building. 

  • This project provided significant professional development for new engineering education doctoral students. Both study sites established new engineering education programs during the course of this project. Through this project, the project faculty mentored and supported six graduate students in developing engineering education research skills to support their own doctoral research. Additionally, two graduate students participated in non-academic internships with non-profit organizations. Student professional development opportunities through the project were abundant. 

  • Faculty involved in this project also taught FYE classes and applied many of the principles from the project to their teaching (e.g., developing an engineering mindset as a way to connect to all disciplines). They also collaborated with colleagues at their institutions to use project findings to improve other elements of FYE programs. 

  • Project findings were used to support the establishment of a department-level student success center at one of the participating institutions. Center activities are designed based on project findings to emphasize student engagement and support student communities throughout all levels of students? degree program. 

 

In summary, this project produced four key findings and associated evidence that can be used to improve student experiences and engineering formation throughout engineering student degree programs. This project had significant, positive impact related to growing the capacity for FYE research for both faculty and students. Additionally, the project provided data necessary to effect changes and improvements to courses and student support activities. 


Last Modified: 04/13/2022
Modified by: Rachel L Kajfez

Our work generated an understanding of how engineering students experience community and the transition from first-year engineering (FYE) student (i.e., freshman or entering transfer student) to the point where they enter (or choose not to enter) the engineering workforce. We interviewed 36 unique students over three years (some completing one, some completing two and some completing three interviews) at two different main institutions and two regional campuses connected to the main institutions to understand how the vastly different first-year engineering programs that they experienced contributed to their development as students and future engineers. The project protocols (e.g., surveys and interview questions) and methods (e.g., procedures for writing extended memos) have been published and can be used in other research projects. 



 


The key findings (intellectual merit contributions) of this project are as follows: 




Across the pathways, students must claim their engineering identity. Often this is claimed after a significant engineering experience such an internship.  


Participants in the common first year structure were more likely to identify themselves as engineers because of their mindset or way of thinking than those in a direct matriculation structure.  


When engineering is not aligned with personal identity, students find an alternate career in which to use their engineering skills or focus on a new discipline or niche area within their current discipline.  








Though there are deliberate attempts to create community within FYE, these communities are not long-standing. Later in the degree program, communities form more naturally and in more diverse ways (e.g., study groups, professional organizations, special interests). These naturally formed communities tend to be more impactful than the communities formed within FYE.

This project provided significant professional development for faculty in the area of engineering education. Project personnel led a workshop at a regional conference and seminars at their own institutions to develop skills in engineering education research methods. Both study sites established new engineering education programs during the course of this project. Through this project, the project faculty mentored and supported six graduate students in developing engineering education research skills to support their own doctoral research. Additionally, two graduate students participated in non-academic internships with non-profit organizations. Student professional development opportunities through the project were abundant. 








Faculty involved in this project also taught FYE classes and applied many of the principles from the project to their teaching (e.g., developing an engineering mindset as a way to connect to all disciplines). They also collaborated with colleagues at their institutions to use project findings to improve other elements of FYE programs. 


Project findings were used to support the establishment of a department-level student success center at one of the participating institutions. Center activities are designed based on project findings to emphasize student engagement and support student communities throughout all levels of students? degree program. 




 


In summary, this project produced four key findings and associated evidence that can be used to improve student experiences and engineering formation throughout engineering student degree programs. This project had significant, positive impact related to growing the capacity for FYE research for both faculty and students. Additionally, the project provided data necessary to effect changes and improvements to courses and student support activities.
